title: 103_hr929
content: The text discusses the simplification of employment taxes on domestic services, including an increase in the threshold requirement from $50 to $300 and the coordination of collection of domestic service employment with income taxes. SEC. 3510 discusses the coordination of collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes. The general rule for domestic service employment taxes requires returns to be filed on a calendar year basis by the 15th day of the fourth month following the employer's taxable year. No deposits or installments are required for these taxes. Domestic service employment taxes are subject to estimated tax provisions under section 6654. For section 6654, domestic service employment taxes are treated as taxes imposed by chapter 2 for the employer's taxable year. Adjustments may be made under regulations for annualization purposes. A transitional rule applies for taxable years beginning in 1994, increasing the amount referred to in section 6654(d)(1)(B) by 90 percent of the tax amount under paragraph (1). The term 'domestic service employment taxes' is defined for this section. For section 6654, domestic service employment taxes are considered as taxes imposed by chapter 2 for the employer's taxable year. The term 'domestic service employment taxes' refers to taxes on remuneration for domestic service in a private home and amounts withheld from such remuneration. The definition excludes service described in section 3121(g)(5). This section does not apply to employers liable for other employment taxes, as determined by the Secretary's regulations. The Secretary may exempt employers liable for other employment taxes from section 6654. Regulations will be prescribed to carry out the purposes of this section, including coordinating domestic service employment taxes with domestic employers' income taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements to collect state unemployment taxes. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with states to collect their unemployment taxes on domestic service employment in private homes. Taxes collected will be transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund. The Secretary can enter agreements with states to collect unemployment taxes on domestic service employment in private homes. The collected taxes will be transferred to the state's account in the Unemployment Trust Fund and treated as a tax imposed by chapter 23 for purposes of Subtitle F. The term 'State' is defined as per section 3306(j)(1). The amendments in Sec. 3510 coordinate the collection of domestic service employment taxes with income taxes, effective for remuneration paid after 1993.
